Award.AwardTitle: Geometry and dynamics of outer automorphism groups of free groups
Award.AbstractNarration:
Geometry group theory is the study of geometric objects and their groups of symmetries using mathematical tools such as algebra, topology, and analysis, with a special emphasis on "large scale" or "quasi-isometric" tools which are used in studies of a geometric object as if viewing it through more and more powerful telescopes. In this project the PI will apply the methods of geometric group theory to the study of hidden symmetries of finite networks known to topologists as "graphs". These groups of hidden symmetries are known as "outer automorphism groups of free groups". One outcome of this project will be to solve important problems in the large scale geometry of outer automorphism groups of free groups and through these solutions to produce new tools of large scale geometry for broad use by the geometric group theory community. Another outcome will be to build tools for a new study of the dynamical properties of outer automorphism groups of free groups.

Outer automorphism groups of finite rank free groups, denoted Out(F_n), were first examined in the 1930's by Nielsen and Whitehead. Interest in Out(F_n) has expanded rapidly in recent decades with the development of geometric tools such as: the Culler-Vogtmann outer space; and the relative train track maps of Bestvina-Feighn-Handel. More recently Out(F_n) is being studied using quasi-isometric geometry, an effort in which the principal investigator has played a leading role. In this project the PI will study actions of finitely generated subgroups of Out(F_n) on hyperbolic metric spaces, attempting to build for Out(F_n) an analogue of the hierarchy theory for mapping class groups of surfaces that was built in the 1990's by Masur and Minsky. As applications, and as guides to building a useful hierarchy theory, the PI plans to study and resolve various problems in the large scale geometry of Out(F_n) including: computation of the 2nd bounded cohomology of finitely generated subgroups of Out(F_n); and early investigations into quasi-isometric rigidity for Out(F_n). The PI also plans to carry out early investigations of certain Out(F_n)-invariant dynamical systems that are analogous to the Teichmuller geodesic flow of a surface and its invariant sets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Geometric group theory is the mathematical study of symmetry combining tools of geometry with tools of algebra, specifically group theory. This project was designed to make progress in geometric group theory through a deep study of the symmetry groups known as “outer automorphism groups of finite rank free groups” which mathematicians denote as Out(F_n). These groups Out(F_n) are important in their own right, as mathematical models of the hidden symmetries of finite networks — in more mathematical language, as groups of homotopy equivalences of graphs. They are also very useful as crucibles for testing broader questions and conjectures in geometry group theory. 

 

Over the last twenty five years, a deep study of other classes of symmetry groups has resulted in a new and important method in geometric group theory known as “hierarchy theory” or “hierarchical hyperbolicity”. With its current scope, hierarchy theory is too limited to reveal anything about Out(F_n). And yet, there are too many coincidences between the behavior predicted by hierarchy theory and the behavior exhibited by Out(F_n). 

 

The general aim of this project was to widen the scope of hierarchy theory for a two-fold purpose: to more deeply understand Out(F_n); and to discover a broader version of hierarchy theory for application within geometric group theory. The specific plan for this project, which was successful, was to broaden hierarchy theory methods for the purpose of computing mathematical invariants known as the “second bounded cohomology of finitely generated subgroups of Out(F_n)”. The new hierarchy theory methods developed for this computation have also led to the development of new avenues of research, the pursuit of which are continuing. 

 

The activities carried out under this project also led to broader impacts on the training of young mathematical researchers. These activities included advising advanced PhD students in general methods of mathematical research, in specific methods of geometric group theory, and in writing their PhD dissertations, leading up to the granting of their PhD degrees. Also, these activities included composition of large parts of a monograph on Out(F_n) aimed at beginning PhD students, for purposes of teaching them some of the specific mathematical methods of geometric group theory.
